MPC and Plant David M. Ratcliffe are committed to maintaining a high standard of Health, Environmental, Safety, and Security performance.  MPC and Plant David M. Ratcliffe are also dedicated to being a good neighbor in our community through open, constructive dialog and input from stakeholders on issues of mutual interest.  These principles are an integral part of our vision and values.



Accident Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 



At Plant David M. Ratcliffe, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our porcesses in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety or our employees, contractors, and the public as well as protection of the environment.  We strive for the goal of no accidents, injuries, unsafe work practices, of unsafe conditions.



REGULATED SUBSTANCES



At David M. Ratcliffe, we currently generate electricity with gas turbines that utilize anydrous ammonia (NH3) in our SCR to reduce our Nitrogen oxide emissions.  



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



At Plant David M. Ratcliffe, we take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases.  This approach to prevention is implemented through programs that incorporate requirements of the EPA Risk Managemaent Plan, the OSHA Process Safety Mangagement standard, and the American Chemistry Council Responsible Care iniative.  In addition to these programs, we have implemented chemical-specific safety features to help monitor, detect, and mitigate accidental releases such as hydrocarbon and gas detectors, deinventory systems, redundant instrumentation and controls, fire suppression and extinguishing systems, and pesonal protective equipment.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 



We have had no accidents to report



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



At Plant David M. Ratcliffe, we have developed an integrated contingency plan which consolidates all of

the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our written program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, contractors, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition, procedures are in place to address maintencance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  The overall emergency response program for the facility is coordinated with an external Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC)



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



At Plant David M. Ratcliffe, we strive to improve the safety of our operations through periodic safety audits, incident investigations, process hazard analysis, and the solicitation of safety suggestions from employees.
